block.p: Re ''Companies Ended Soft Donations but Still Play the Influence Game'' (front page, Aug. 4):
Re ''Companies Ended Soft Donations but Still Play the Influence Game'' (front page, Aug. 4):

Since Time Warner announced in 1999 that it would no longer make so-called soft-money contributions to political parties or organizations, our company has budgeted an additional $2 million for expanded campaign coverage by our CNN, Time, Fortune and Money news organizations and the 24-hour news services offered by five of our cable systems. Money that was formerly earmarked for contributions is now being used to enhance our political coverage.
We hope to foster meaningful debate and increased citizen participation in the political process and help improve the access voters have to intelligent, in-depth coverage of the issues.
EDWARD ADLER Senior V.P., Corporate Communications, Time Warner New York, Aug. 7, 2000
